thread.title: Judge calls for law change after man squatted in ex-partner's house
thread.title_full: Judge calls for law change after man squatted in ex-partner's house

author: Elizabeth Byrne
title: Judge calls for law change after man squatted in ex-partner's house
text:
Map: Canberra 2600 
A Canberra judge says the ACT's trespass laws need to change, after a man successfully squatted in the home of his dead ex-partner for more than a year, before being forcibly removed. 
Authorities evicted the man from the house, which was purchased under the name of his deceased estranged wife, this morning. 
The woman left Queensland with her three children in 2014 after a serious domestic violence incident, settling in Canberra, where she bought the house. 
When she died of cancer in 2015, her brother became the executor of her estate, and guardian of the children who now live with him, backed up by a family court ruling. 
But shortly after the woman died her former husband moved into her house. 
The woman's brother has been trying for more than a year to have him removed, after a trespass order from the ACT Civil And Administrative Tribunal (ACAT). 
The order was eventually enforced by Supreme Court Judge Richard Refshauge, who expressed frustration about the delay in the case. 
"It seems undesirable that these proceedings should have become so complex," he said. 
Justice Refshauge blamed a gap in trespass laws and called for a change. 
He said under the current law ACAT must refer the enforcement to the Magistrates Court, which has no power to recover land, which meant that the case had to be referred on to the Supreme Court. 
He has suggested either ACAT or the Magistrates Court could be given direct powers to enforce trespass laws, or matters could go straight to the Supreme Court, as in the case of heritage questions.
